channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Russia 'will respect Crimea vote'
item.description: Russia will "respect the will of the people of Crimea", Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov says ahead of Sunday's controversial referendum.

item.title: Indian Ocean search for missing jet
item.description: The US sends search crews to the Indian Ocean, after claims emerge that the missing Malaysian airliner may have flown longer than thought.

item.title: Police 'fury' over Pistorius watches
item.description: A former police officer says he was "furious" when two of Oscar Pistorius' watches went missing from the crime scene, his murder trial hears.

item.title: 'Hundreds' attack Nigerian city
item.description: Hundreds of militants stage a multi-pronged attack on the northern Nigerian city of Maiduguri, including the army barracks, witnesses say.

item.title: Labour stalwart Tony Benn dies at 88
item.description: Veteran British Labour politician Tony Benn has died at home at the age of 88, his family says.

item.title: Site ordered to remove Sarkozy tapes
item.description: A French court orders a news website to remove files of secretly taped conversations involving Nicolas Sarkozy during his time as president.

item.title: Time to honour Syria 'promises'
item.description: The head of Syria's main opposition coalition tells the BBC international allies must honour what he says were promises to supply heavy weapons to the Free Syrian Army.

item.title: Three convicted over India nun rape
item.description: A court in India finds three people guilty in connection with the rape of a Catholic nun in the eastern state of Orissa in 2008.

item.title: Deadly knife attack in south China
item.description: A knife attack following a dispute at a marketplace in China's southern Hunan province leaves six people dead, police say.

item.title: More stem cell 'discovery' doubts
item.description: A Japanese investigation into a supposedly groundbreaking stem cell study has discovered "inappropriate handling" of the data.

item.title: No review of Japan sex slave apology
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe says he will not revise a historic apology for the army's use of Asian women as war-time sex slaves.

item.title: Hoeness resigns as Bayern president
item.description: Bayern Munich president Uli Hoeness resigns after being found guilty of evading taxes worth Â£22.5m (27m euros).

item.title: Free Paris transport to reduce smog
item.description: French officials make public transport in the capital, Paris, free for three days to reduce severe pollution caused by unusually warm weather.

item.title: VIDEO: Homs: Living under siege
item.description: A video sent to the BBC by activist group Masarat, shows what life is like for people in the besieged city of Homs.

item.title: VIDEO: US plane emergency evacuation
item.description: Footage filmed by a passenger shows people leaving the plane on inflatable ramps

item.title: VIDEO: One-minute World News
item.description: Watch the latest news summary from BBC World News. International news updated 24 hours a day.

item.title: VIDEO: Astronaut asks public to name mission
item.description: Astronaut Tim Peake has asked the public to propose a name for his mission to the International Space Station.

item.title: VIDEO: Expert handled gun 'without gloves'
item.description: The Oscar Pistorius murder trial has heard that a ballistics expert at the crime scene handled the gun found there without wearing gloves.

item.title: VIDEO: Free travel in Paris as pollution rises
item.description: Free public transport is being offered to Parisians this weekend as the authorities encourage drivers to leave their cars at home in an attempt to combat severe pollution.

item.title: VIDEO: Syria conflict: is it stalemate?
item.description: Paul Adams examines the major developments over the last year in the Syria conflict.

item.title: VIDEO: The sci-fi classic that never got made
item.description: Tom Brook looks under the cover of a failed attempt to make an adaptation of Frank Herbert's epic novel Dune.

item.title: VIDEO: Gorilla born by Caesarean section
item.description: San Diego Zoo Safari Park releases footage of a newborn gorilla which was delivered by a rare Caesarean section after complications arose during labour.

item.title: Hail storm blankets Eritrean capital
item.description: Hail is piled one metre high in Asmara, capital of Eritrea, after the heaviest rainfall ever recorded.

item.title: UBS traders tried to rig key rate
item.description: Traders at Swiss bank UBS made around 100 attempts to rig Hong Kong's interbank lending market, financial regulators have said.

item.title: US lifts BP government contract ban
item.description: The US lifts a ban on oil giant BP that prevented it from bidding for US government contracts.

item.title: Moscow blocks four anti-Putin sites
item.description: Moscow has blocked access to four websites run by opponents and critics of President Vladimir Putin.

item.title: Europe backs single phone charger
item.description: European politicians have backed a regulation that will force smartphone makers to use just one type of charger.

item.title: Japan arrest over Anne Frank attacks
item.description: Police in Japan arrest a man suspected of vandalising copies of Anne Frank's diaries and related material.

item.title: Rocky makes strong debut on Broadway
item.description: 'Stage magic' triumphs over lacklustre music to win critics approval as big screen hit Rocky opens on Broadway

item.title: UK scientists call for new GM trials
item.description: There should be more UK field trials and fewer EU restrictions on genetically modified (GM) crops, a report commissioned by the prime minister says.

item.title: UK astronaut's mission needs a name
item.description: The European Space Agency asks people to choose a name for British astronaut Major Tim Peake's next mission.

item.title: Takeout food ban 'may fight obesity'
item.description: Restricting the number of fast-food outlets around offices and homes could help combat the obesity epidemic, UK researchers say.

item.title: Rare US woman-to-woman HIV case
item.description: US health officials publish details of a rare case of suspected female-to-female HIV infection, reported in the state of Texas.

item.title: Lord Windermere wins Gold Cup
item.description: Lord Windermere wins a thrilling Cheltenham Gold Cup from 20-1 by edging On His Own in a photo finish.

item.title: The Moomins in love and war
item.description: She was an upper-middle-class Finnish lesbian bohemian - but Tove Jansson speaks directly to children and adults all over the world.

item.title: VIDEO: The beauty of scars
item.description: Photographer David Jay tells the BBC he hopes his portraits of people with breast cancer and severely wounded veterans will help redefine what people see as beautiful.

item.title: Adichie wins US fiction honour
item.description: Nigerian author Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie wins the US National Critics Book Prize for her novel Americanah.

item.title: Google encrypts searches in China
item.description: Google has started to encrypt searches made by people in China as it beefs up protection against surveillance.

item.title: Stolen bank cards highest since 2006
item.description: Consumers are being warned about a series of bank card scams, after fraud from stolen cards rose to its highest level in eight years, says the UK Cards Association

item.title: Kerry attacks Venezuela's 'terror'
item.description: US Secretary of State John Kerry says Venezuela's government must end its "terror campaign against its own citizens", as protests continue.

item.title: Israel-Gaza strikes despite 'truce'
item.description: Rocket and air strikes continue between Gaza militants and Israel despite earlier claims a truce had been restored.

item.title: New York blast site rescue continues
item.description: Rescue operations continue two days after a gas leak and explosion demolished two buildings in New York City, killing eight and injuring scores.

item.title: Morrisons hit by massive data theft
item.description: The majority of staff at Morrisons have been affected by the theft of payroll data, the company has said.

item.title: Crash peer 'concern' over helicopter
item.description: A Northern Ireland peer killed in an air crash in Norfolk along with three others, had raised concerns about a helicopter he owned, the BBC learns.

item.title: Clifford 'exposed himself to model'
item.description: A court has heard that publicist Max Clifford exposed himself to a model during a meeting at his office 25 years ago.

item.title: BT investigated over email data
item.description: BT is being investigated by the UK's data authority following whistleblower claims the company "exposed user credentials en masse".

item.title: In pictures: Violence in Donetsk
item.description: Pro-Russian and pro-Kiev supporters clash

item.title: In pictures: New York building blast
item.description: Emergency crews respond to an explosion

item.title: In pictures: Turkey mourns boy killed in protests
item.description: Thousands join funeral of a Berkin Elvan

item.title: Your pictures: Delicate
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme of delicate

item.title: Day in pictures: 12 March 2014
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 12 March

item.title: In pictures: Rail union chief
item.description: RMT general secretary Bob Crow dies

item.title: Day in pictures: 11 March 2014
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 11 March

item.title: In pictures: Cornish Bards
item.description: A student's portraits of Cornish Bards

item.title: On the trail of the mysterious Mont Blanc treasure
item.description: On the trail of the hidden Mont Blanc treasure

item.title: Could tipping baristas become the norm?
item.description: Is tipping coffee baristas a step too far?

item.title: Syria: The story of the conflict
item.description: Eight steps to understanding the bitter conflict

item.title: Mechanical v human: Why do planes crash?
item.description: What are the reasons behind planes crashing?

item.title: Day in pictures: 14 March 2014
item.description: News images from around the world over the past 24 hours

item.title: Jamaica's marijuana growers split on legalisation
item.description: Why Jamaican marijuana growers are split on legalisation

item.title: Why the Great War still fascinates the young
item.description: Why the Great War still fascinates the young

item.title: The allure of an old-fashioned pen pal
item.description: Rediscovering the allure of a pen pal in the digital age

item.title: Quiz of the week's news
item.description: Which song did the Rolling Stones say they were told not to play?

item.title: VIDEO: Reflecting the changing face of Asia
item.description: Photographer reflects changing face of Asia's modern cities

item.title: Finding America's future farmers
item.description: US turns to minorities to find farmers of the future

item.title: Big data puts the doctor in your pocket
item.description: Health data boom heralding new era of personalised medicine

item.title: Ukraine maps chart Crimea's troubled past
item.description: Maps chart Crimea's troubled past

item.title: Co-operation and controversy in Iran
item.description: Ashton visit to Iran sparks co-operation and controversy
